What if, and this might be completely crazy, but what if as the Shuriman story progresses and it comes to light that Azir is not in fact a villain out to enslave anyone, that Taliyah abandons her ill-founded hatred for the god-emperor? Azir is so impressed by her resolve to prevent anything harming her family of Shurima that he offers her assistance in understanding her powers. He has considerable mastery over sand and miscellaneous magic, and sand is just tiny rocks, so he must have some valuable information that can assist her, and if not, he is a gosh darn god-emperor; he can get her the training she needs.

Azir discovers someone who wants to protect Shurima as much as he does, and Taliyah learns the evil overlord out to enslave her people just wants to give them a better standard of living, though he is a little out of touch with the times. Bam. Through mutual interests a friendship is formed across hundreds of generations. Taliyah becomes the poster child of Shuriman patriotism and Azir is the emperor he always wanted to be, beloved by the people. The Late Kingdom rises from the dust of history and naught but the jaws of Apep can cast it down.

Abraham Lincoln freed the slaves as a strategic move in the war effort. Azir did it selflessly.
Especially since his not telling Xerath comes off as a huge breach of trust and confidence. Did he think Xerath would blab to everyone?

"He instituted reforms to better the lives of slaves and privately developed a plan to overturn millennia of tradition and eventually free them all. He kept his plans secret, even from Xerath, and the issue of slavery would prove to be a continual bone of contention between them. The empire had been built on the back of slavery, and many of the great noble houses depended on enforced labor for their vast wealth and power. Such monolithic institutions could not be overturned overnight, and Azir’s plans would be undone were they to become common knowledge. Despite Azir’s desire to name Xerath his brother, he could not do so until all Shurima’s slaves were free."

That's all it says on the subject. Maybe Azir just assumed Xerath was happy where he was at or something? He did tell Xerath he would free him a long time ago. Maybe Xerath assumed Azir changed his mind, but Azir never considered the way Xerath felt and just assumed Xerath trusted him?

The line "He kept his plans secret, even from Xerath," implies that he felt that telling Xerath would be a liability somehow. Xerath, the one person who has always been on his side. Xerath his ever competent brother.

I hope Azir's humility didn't end with Sivir's healing.

I doubt it ended there.

Azir has always struck me as proud, but not arrogant, and death seemed to have left a considerable mark on his ego. I mean, it speaks a lot about someone's character when their first thought on being resurrected, following what was perhaps the most traumatic moment of their existence, is to save a life.

I am certain the god-emperor would be none to pleased by someone breaking down his door and assaulting him, but let us be honest, he is a god-freaking-emperor. Taliyah throwing some rocks at him may be annoying at best, laughable at worst. And that is assuming she would shoot first and ask questions later; Taliyah strikes me as someone still invested in romantic thoughts like those of myth and legend, planning on making a grand entrance to righteously demand the emancipation of her people. At which point Azir would breakdown laughing, leaving her more than a little confused. An explanation would follow and they can put the whole misunderstanding behind them.

Not to hit someone when they are down, but when did Azir fight hard to gain control of the Shuriman empire. Seems like Xerath did all the work saving him from raiders, killing contenders to the throne, helping with his education...

So Xerath did not kill all the mercenaries attacking his camo. In fact Azir used a knife and drove the knife into a mercenaries neck before the battle was over. Now that Azir was the contender for the throne and hated by his father, Azir devoted himself to earning the title of Emperor, serving on Renekton to learn how to fight, control troops, and feel the turn and tide of war. Xerath might have done a lot of work himself, but that was for his own gain. He was Azir's best friend, and as long as Azir was in power, so was he and the lore even states that he eventually becomes corrupted by the want of power. So corrupted that despite the fact that Azir granted Xerath his one wish, for him and all slaves to be free, he still betrays him to become an ascended being
